section.para: From the origin the &productName; compiler has been built in order to allow maximum flexibility. The downside of this choice is the inflation of the generated code and a loss of performances.
In the embedded software world it happens regularly that we have to integrate software on very constrained devices (low RAM and Flash memory amounts).
By applying optimizations we keep the advantages of Fractal architecture while keeping the performance of pure C.

note.para: Optimizations allow to remove the overhead but break the separation between component definitions and instances (in Object-Oriented Programming, compare to classes and objects).
We have to make hypotheses about the instantiation context of a definition in order to optimize a client interface invocation.
There is an opposition between optimization and separate compilation.
A definition compiled with some optimizations may not be reusable.

section.para: This document is intended for developers who wish to reduce the memory footprint of their embedded applications and gain performance for some specific features.

section.para: Ways provided by the &productName; compiler to optimize the application are ADL annotations or global extension.

para.note: Global extensions (.ext files) are defined outside ADLs.
Annotations are associated to specific keywords of the MIND language.
The developer has to identify the code parts to be optimized, following requirements.

section.para: By default the optimization backend (activated by the -O option) limit the generation of fractal factories to the factories declared in ADL. This optimization does not reduce the flexibility of the application, and can already lead to significant reduction of the code sections.
This mechanism allows to apply optimizations on specific components without ADL code intrusion.
This mechanism is materialized by ext files referenced in the Ext.properties file.

note.para: global extension are applicable on components and bindings but not one interfaces.

section.para: The Flatten annotation allows to suppress all composites. The final architecture is in the flattened view of all components. The top-level component resulting of the architecture transformation will directly contain all your primitives, and "delegation bindings" (going through composites) will be merged.
section.note: This annotation can also be used with the extraOptions (.properties file).

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: No condition.

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: All optimization annotations applied on connections between several composite/primitive encapsulated in composites are suppressed.
So be careful when this annotation is used in conjunction with Static/StaticBindings...annotations.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: This annotation allows to reduce foot print and call time: Calls do not need to go through the membrane of composites.

section.para: The Static annotation allows to perform a single direct call between a client and a server interface.
This annotation must be attached to a binding definition.

note.para: This annotation is applicable on collections.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: Both client and server must be singleton.
If one of them is not a singleton than the static annotation has no effect and a warning is generated in the compilation time.

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: The binding between client A and server B can't be removed.
Another client A' still has the possibility to be dynamically bound to the server B.
The B interface still can be discovered

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: This annotation mainly reduces the call time between a client and a server interface.
It also reduces memory data use on the client side.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: The @Static annotation is described in the file optimisation/staticbinding/StaticBindingApplication.adl
The binding between the client interface of the component bootStrap and the server interface of the component SingletonComponent is static.

formalpara.title: Annotation fields
formalpara.para: No field

section.para: The Singleton annotation specifies that the definition can be instantiated only a single time in a given application. An error is reported by the &productName; toolchain if a definition with this annotation is instantiated more that once in an application.

note.para: Composite definitions that contain at least one singleton sub-component are implicitly declared singleton. A warning is raised in this case. It is recommended to add explicitly the Singleton annotation on such a composite definition.
Instantiating a generic definition by passing a singleton definition as value results in a singleton definition.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: No condition

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: The annotated component can't be instantiated several times.

note.para: Using Mind macros-annotated code from standard C functions is made possible.
Use of global data as PRIVATE is made safe, which is usefull when componentizing legacy C code.
Knowing the component will be unique in the application allows the @StaticBindings annotation to make strong assumptions for further optimizations.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: But using the @Singleton annotation is mandatory for some other optimizations.

section.para: The StaticBindings annotation is available for developers to declare that all bindings in the composite must be static, and no reconfiguration features are used.
This annotation is used on composite definition.

note.para: This annotation is applicable on collections.
Remove all meta data in the server interfaces.
Equivalent to the generalization of the Static annotation for all bindings inside the composite.
If there's no attribute , no controller and no sub-components then all the "glue" is removed.
If two instances of the component are absolutely mandatory you can duplicate the component by using inheritance.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: All sub-components must be singleton.
This uniqueness of components is a mandatory pre-condition for StaticBindings allowing very strong assumptions during code generation.
Any reconfiguration using BIND_MY_INTERFACE or Fractal controllers is strictly impossible and forbidden. Compilation will fail otherwise. Warning: No incompatibility verification is done yet.

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: Removes all possibility of dynamic binding for the selected composite.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: This annotation allows reducing the application's memory footprint and reduce call time between sub-components.
The footprint gain depends on the user code. The smaller the user code, greater the gain.
Interface data is removed both from clients and servers side.

formalpara.title: Remarks (March 2014, 19th)
formalpara.para: Bindings with source or destination collection interfaces are NOT supported in the previous releases, as well as bindings leading to controllers: They are tolerated but never optimized.

Next compiler releases will support collections optimization both as binding source or destination. This should speed up execution with collections, hopefully gain in data sections, but can (to this day) sometimes result in data section growth. Keep in touch with the Mind team for further information (development in progress).

section.para: The GarbageUnusedInternal annotation allows to remove residual generated code resulting of the usage of the StaticBindings annotation.
This annotation is used on composite definitions.

note.para: This removes unused code for composite and primitive definitions (Optimal case removes the totality of the membrane code).
This annotation is destined to be merged with the StaticBindings annotation.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: For this annotation to be completely efficient, you should not use collections, unbound client interfaces, or controllers, in the composite.

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: Detects all possible cases where @StaticBindings can generate empty structures. Compilers such as GCC tolerate those and reserve space in BSS section, however embedded compilers such as IAR completely forbid empty structures and stop compilation with an error.
Using @GarbageUnusedInternals allows avoiding this pitfall.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: This annotation allows to reduce the memory application's footprint (BSS section).

example.title: The @GarbageUnusedInternal annotation
example.para: The GarbageUnusedInternal annotation is used in conjunction with the StaticBindings annotation.

section.para: The StaticDefinitionBindingsList annotation allows to connect explicitly one or several client interface of a component to a server interface of a component definition.
Function call is « frozen » for the specified unique target definition (no other) at compilation time.

note.para: The call function is blocked on a component definition.
The client component and the server component are not necessary singleton.
The server component type can be instanciated several time in the composite.
Neither server collection nor client collection are supported with this optimization.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: The server component is not singleton.
The client and server interface must be single (no collection)

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: Dynamic binding change with BIND_MY_INTERFACE is only possible with components of the specified server definition type. Components from other definitions cannot be bound anymore.

formalpara.title: Remark
formalpara.para: CALL_PTR which can be used as thread-safe and lock-free alternative to BIND_MY_INTERFACE for highly-dynamic binding. Can be optimized in in a very similar way, see the FreezeCallPointer annotation.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: This annotation allows reducing call time while keeping partial flexibility. This is useful for intensive calls to large pools of components of the same type (definition).

formalpara.title: Annotation fields
formalpara.para: @FreezeCallPointer(toItf="<component definition.server interface>")

section.para: The FreezeCallPointer annotation allows to call an explicit server interface via an interface pointer (macro CALL_PTR), in an optimized way. Its objective is the same as StaticDefinitionBinding, but allows to optimize the CALL_PTR (which is thread-safe and lock-free), while calling a pool of target component instances (restricted to the same target definition, like StaticDefinitionBinding).

note.para: The required interface must be removed.

formalpara.title: Usage condition
formalpara.para: No declaration of the server interface in the client ADL component.

formalpara.title: Consequences
formalpara.para: The client interface can't be bound to components interfaces from another server definition.
CALL_PTR can target only the specific interface of components from the type (definition) specified in the annotation argument, and no other, in the whole scope of the component.
Compared to StaticDefinitionBinding, you lose the expressivity of the required interface in the architecture.

formalpara.title: Gains
formalpara.para: The compiler does direct calls to the server interface. This reduces calls time.

This optimization is an alternative to StaticDefinitionBinding, for intensive calls to large pools of components of the same type (definition). With StaticDefinitionBinding, you use BIND_MY_INTERFACE to choose the target of the calls, and then use the CALL macro. With FreezeCallPointer, you simply use CALL_PTR and do not need to use BIND_MY_INTERFACE. As BIND_MY_INTERFACE has an effect on a variable (stateful action), multi-threaded applications could cause trouble during this action. CALL_PTR being stateless, safe and lock-free multi-threading is possible within the component while targetting different components.
